importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Retail coffee prices increased nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the same period the previous year, highlighting a direct economic impact of tariffs on consumer spending.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from July to September 2025 includes the imposition of new tariffs and the introduction of the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act', marking a critical policy and market response phase.

keyTakeAways: Trump administration tariffs have significantly increased the cost of imported coffee beans, especially from Brazil, Vietnam, and Colombia.
Brazil faces a 50% tariff, Vietnam a 20%, and Colombia a 10%, which directly impacts the cost of coffee beans for U.S. roasters.
The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil supplying 30.7% of imports, followed by Colombia (18.3%) and Vietnam (6.6%).
Average restaurant coffee prices rose to $3.52 in August 2025, up 10 cents from the previous year.
In Washington, D.C., a regular hot coffee averaged $4.21 and cold brew $5.35, both up 3–4% year-over-year.
Small roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting have reported increased costs and operational strain due to tariffs and supply issues.
A 50% tariff on Brazilian coffee, exacerbated by drought-related supply shortages, has the most significant impact on roasters and consumers.
Consumers may switch brands or reduce quality in their coffee choices, but are unlikely to abandon consumption due to coffee’s status as an affordable luxury.
A bipartisan bill, the 'No Coffee Tax Act', was introduced in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs, signaling a potential policy shift.
Uncertainty around pricing and supply chains is creating financial strain on small and medium-sized coffee businesses, affecting long-term planning and sustainability.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, making it highly vulnerable to international price fluctuations and tariff changes impacting domestic pricing and consumer behavior.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration’s imposition of steep tariffs—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—has significantly raised the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to a 21% year-over-year increase in restaurant coffee prices. With the U.S. importing over 99% of its coffee and relying heavily on Brazilian and Colombian supplies, roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting are facing rising costs and operational challenges. Consumers in major markets like Washington, D.C., are paying more, with average coffee prices rising by 3–4% year-over-year. Despite these pressures, coffee remains an affordable luxury, and consumers are likely to maintain consumption habits. In response, a bipartisan group of lawmakers introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' to exempt coffee from tariffs, signaling potential policy relief.
title: Trump’s tariffs are brewing trouble for coffee roasters
